title: How a command line is interpreted
b
The parsing of a command line into a sequence of commands is complex, and varies subtly from command interpreter to command interpreter. There are, however, four main components:

inline_content.Text: The parsing of a command line into a sequence of commands is complex, and varies subtly from command interpreter to command interpreter. There are, however, four main components:

title: A command line is scanned for variable specifications, and any found are replaced with the contents of those variables.

inline_content.Text: A command line is scanned for variable specifications, and any found are replaced with the contents of those variables.

title: `Special characters can be quoted, to remove their special meanings.

inline_content.Text: `Special characters can be quoted, to remove their special meanings.

title: Command lines are developed into a sequence of commands according to a syntax.

inline_content.Text: Command lines are developed into a sequence of commands according to a syntax.

title: Redirection specifications are applied, and removed from the command line, before an individual command in a sequence is executed.

inline_content.Text: Redirection specifications are applied, and removed from the command line, before an individual command in a sequence is executed.

title: Command lines can contain variable specifications. These comprise a % character followed by a name, followed by a second % character unless the name is a digit in 0 ... 9 or an asterisk *.

inline_content.Text: Command lines can contain variable specifications. These comprise a % character followed by a name, followed by a second % character unless the name is a digit in 0 ... 9 or an asterisk *.

title: Variable specifications are replaced with values as follows:

inline_content.Text: Variable specifications are replaced with values as follows:

title: %%, such as %PATH% or %USERNAME%, is replaced with the value of the named environment variable. For example, %PATH% is replaced by the value of the PATH environment variable.

inline_content.Text: %%, such as %PATH% or %USERNAME%, is replaced with the value of the named environment variable. For example, %PATH% is replaced by the value of the PATH environment variable.

title: % for 0 <= n <= 9, such as %0 or %9, is replaced with the value of the n-th parameter passed to the batch file when it was invoked, subject to any subsequent modifications by the
SHIFT
a
https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Windows_Batch_Scripting#SHIFT
command. For example: %2 is replaced by the value of the second batch file parameter.

inline_content.Text: % for 0 <= n <= 9, such as %0 or %9, is replaced with the value of the n-th parameter passed to the batch file when it was invoked, subject to any subsequent modifications by the
command. For example: %2 is replaced by the value of the second batch file parameter.

title: %* is replaced with the values of all the command-line parameters except for %0, even those beyond index 9.
SHIFT
a
https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Windows_Batch_Scripting#SHIFT
command has no impact on the result of %*. See also
Command-line arguments
a
https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Windows_Batch_Scripting#Command-line_arguments

inline_content.Text: %* is replaced with the values of all the command-line parameters except for %0, even those beyond index 9.
command has no impact on the result of %*. See also

title: Some variable names are not visible using
SET
a
https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Windows_Batch_Scripting#SET
command. Rather, they are made available for reading using the % notation. To find out about them, type "help set".

inline_content.Text: Some variable names are not visible using
command. Rather, they are made available for reading using the % notation. To find out about them, type "help set".

title: Special variable names and what they expand to:

inline_content.Text: Special variable names and what they expand to:

t2[N: The current directory, not ending in a slash character if it is not the root directory of the current drive
title: %CD%

t2[N: The system time in HH:MM:SS.mm format.
title: %TIME%

t2[N: The system date in a format specific to localization.
title: %DATE%

t2[N: A generated pseudo-random number between 0 and 32767.
title: %RANDOM%

t2[N: The error level returned by the last executed command, or by the last called batch script.
title: %ERRORLEVEL%

t2[N: The version number of the Command Processor Extensions currently used by cmd.exe.
title: %CMDEXTVERSION%

t2[N: The content of the command line used when the current cmd.exe was started.
title: %CMDCMDLINE%
You can prevent the special characters that control command syntax from having their special meanings as follows, except for the percent sign (%):

inline_content.Text: You can prevent the special characters that control command syntax from having their special meanings as follows, except for the percent sign (%):

title: You can surround a string containing a special character by quotation marks.

inline_content.Text: You can surround a string containing a special character by quotation marks.

title: You can place caret (^), an escape character, immediately before the special characters. In a command located after a pipe (|), you need to use three carets (^^^) for this to work.

inline_content.Text: You can place caret (^), an escape character, immediately before the special characters. In a command located after a pipe (|), you need to use three carets (^^^) for this to work.

title: The special characters that need quoting or escaping are usually <, >, |, &, and ^. In some circumstances, ! and \ may need to be escaped. A newline can be escaped using caret as well.

inline_content.Text: The special characters that need quoting or escaping are usually <, >, |, &, and ^. In some circumstances, ! and \ may need to be escaped. A newline can be escaped using caret as well.

title: When you surround the string using quotation marks, they become part of the argument passed to the command invoked. By contrast, when you use caret as an escape character, the caret does not become part of the argument passed.

inline_content.Text: When you surround the string using quotation marks, they become part of the argument passed to the command invoked. By contrast, when you use caret as an escape character, the caret does not become part of the argument passed.

title: The percent sign (%) is a special case. On the command line, it does not need quoting or escaping unless two of them are used to indicate a variable, such as %OS%. But in a batch file, you have to use a double percent sign (%%) to yield a single percent sign (%). Enclosing the percent sign in quotation marks or preceding it with caret does not work.

inline_content.Text: The percent sign (%) is a special case. On the command line, it does not need quoting or escaping unless two of them are used to indicate a variable, such as %OS%. But in a batch file, you have to use a double percent sign (%%) to yield a single percent sign (%). Enclosing the percent sign in quotation marks or preceding it with caret does not work.

title: Echoes the complete string rather than splitting the command line at the & character. Quotes are echoed as well

inline_content.Text: Echoes the complete string rather than splitting the command line at the & character. Quotes are echoed as well

title: As above, but using caret before the special character ampersand. No quotes are echoed.

inline_content.Text: As above, but using caret before the special character ampersand. No quotes are echoed.

title: Does not use an escape character and therefore, "son" is interpreted as a separate command, usually leading to an error message that command son is not found.

inline_content.Text: Does not use an escape character and therefore, "son" is interpreted as a separate command, usually leading to an error message that command son is not found.

title: Echoes A ^ B. Caret needs escaping as well or else it is interpreted as escaping a space.

inline_content.Text: Echoes A ^ B. Caret needs escaping as well or else it is interpreted as escaping a space.

title: Echoes A ^ B. When after a pipe, a caret used for escaping needs to be tripled to work; the fourth caret is the one being escaped.

inline_content.Text: Echoes A ^ B. When after a pipe, a caret used for escaping needs to be tripled to work; the fourth caret is the one being escaped.

title: Echoes the two strings. The caret at the end of the line escapes the newlines, leading to the three lines being treated as if they were a single line. The space before the first caret is necessary or else 1 gets joined with the following echo to yield 1echo.

inline_content.Text: Echoes the two strings. The caret at the end of the line escapes the newlines, leading to the three lines being treated as if they were a single line. The space before the first caret is necessary or else 1 gets joined with the following echo to yield 1echo.

title: Does not show attributes of file named "File 1.txt" since escaping of space does not work. Using quotes, as in attrib "File 1.txt", works.

inline_content.Text: Does not show attributes of file named "File 1.txt" since escaping of space does not work. Using quotes, as in attrib "File 1.txt", works.

title: If run from a batch, the percent sign is ignored.

inline_content.Text: If run from a batch, the percent sign is ignored.

title: If run from a batch, the percent sign is output once.

inline_content.Text: If run from a batch, the percent sign is output once.

title: If run from a batch, sets modulo variable to 2, the remainder of dividing 14 by 3. Does not work with single %.

inline_content.Text: If run from a batch, sets modulo variable to 2, the remainder of dividing 14 by 3. Does not work with single %.

title: If run from a batch, outputs 1, 2 and 3.

inline_content.Text: If run from a batch, outputs 1, 2 and 3.

title: Outputs the content of temp variable even if run from a batch file. Use of the percent sign in a batch to access environment variables and passed arguments needs no escaping.

inline_content.Text: Outputs the content of temp variable even if run from a batch file. Use of the percent sign in a batch to access environment variables and passed arguments needs no escaping.

title: Outputs literally %temp% when run from the command line.

inline_content.Text: Outputs literally %temp% when run from the command line.

title: Outputs literally %temp% when run from a batch.

inline_content.Text: Outputs literally %temp% when run from a batch.

title: Command
FINDSTR
a
https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Windows_Batch_Scripting#FINDSTR
uses backslash (\) for escaping. Unlike caret, this is internal to the command and unknown to the command shell.

inline_content.Text: uses backslash (\) for escaping. Unlike caret, this is internal to the command and unknown to the command shell.

title: Syntax : Escape Characters, Delimiters and Quotes
a
http://ss64.com/nt/syntax-esc.html
at ss64

inline_content.Text: Syntax : Escape Characters, Delimiters and Quotes

title: Command lines are developed into a sequence of commands according to a syntax. In that syntax, simple commandsmay be combined to form pipelines, which may in turn be combined to form compound commands, which finally may be turned into parenthesized commands.

inline_content.Text: Command lines are developed into a sequence of commands according to a syntax. In that syntax, simple commandsmay be combined to form pipelines, which may in turn be combined to form compound commands, which finally may be turned into parenthesized commands.

title: A simple command is just a command name, a command tail, and some redirection specifications. An example of a simple command is dir *.txt > somefile.

inline_content.Text: A simple command is just a command name, a command tail, and some redirection specifications. An example of a simple command is dir *.txt > somefile.

title: A pipeline is several simple commands joined together with the "pipe" metacharacter—"|", also known as the "vertical bar". The standard output of the simple command preceding each vertical bar is connected to the standard input of the simple command following it, via a pipe. The command interpreter runs all of the simple commands in the pipeline in parallel. An example of a pipeline (comprising two simple commands) is dir *.txt | more.

inline_content.Text: A pipeline is several simple commands joined together with the "pipe" metacharacter—"|", also known as the "vertical bar". The standard output of the simple command preceding each vertical bar is connected to the standard input of the simple command following it, via a pipe. The command interpreter runs all of the simple commands in the pipeline in parallel. An example of a pipeline (comprising two simple commands) is dir *.txt | more.

title: A compound command is a set of pipelines separated by conjunctions. The pipelines are executed sequentially, one after the other, and the conjunction controls whether the command interpreter executes the next pipeline or not. An example of a compound command (comprising two pipelines, which themselves are just simple commands) is move file.txt file.bak && dir > file.txt.

inline_content.Text: A compound command is a set of pipelines separated by conjunctions. The pipelines are executed sequentially, one after the other, and the conjunction controls whether the command interpreter executes the next pipeline or not. An example of a compound command (comprising two pipelines, which themselves are just simple commands) is move file.txt file.bak && dir > file.txt.

title: &
b
- An unconditional conjunction. The next pipeline is always executed after the current one has completed executing.

inline_content.Text: - An unconditional conjunction. The next pipeline is always executed after the current one has completed executing.

title: &&
b
- A positive conditional conjunction. The next pipeline is executed if the current one completes executing with a zero exit status.

inline_content.Text: - A positive conditional conjunction. The next pipeline is executed if the current one completes executing with a zero exit status.

title: b
- A negative conditional conjunction. The next pipeline is executed if the current one completes executing with a non-zero exit status.

inline_content.Text: - A negative conditional conjunction. The next pipeline is executed if the current one completes executing with a non-zero exit status.

title: A parenthesized command is a compound command enclosed in parentheses (i.e. ( and )). From the point of view of syntax, this turns a compound command into a simple command, whose overall output can be redirected.

inline_content.Text: A parenthesized command is a compound command enclosed in parentheses (i.e. ( and )). From the point of view of syntax, this turns a compound command into a simple command, whose overall output can be redirected.

title: For example: The command line ( pushd temp & dir & popd ) > somefile causes the standard output of the entire compound command ( pushd temp & dir & popd ) to be redirected to somefile.

inline_content.Text: For example: The command line ( pushd temp & dir & popd ) > somefile causes the standard output of the entire compound command ( pushd temp & dir & popd ) to be redirected to somefile.

title: Using parenthesis/brackets to group expressions at ss64.com
a
http://ss64.com/nt/syntax-brackets.html

inline_content.Text: Using parenthesis/brackets to group expressions at ss64.com

title: Redirection specifications are applied, and removed from the command line, before an individual command in a sequence is executed. Redirection specifications control where the standard input, standard output, and standard error file handles for a simple command point. They override any effects to those file handles that may have resulted from pipelining. (See the preceding section on command syntax.) Redirection signs > and >> can be prefixed with 1 for the standard output (same as no prefix) or 2 for the standard error.

inline_content.Text: Redirection specifications are applied, and removed from the command line, before an individual command in a sequence is executed. Redirection specifications control where the standard input, standard output, and standard error file handles for a simple command point. They override any effects to those file handles that may have resulted from pipelining. (See the preceding section on command syntax.) Redirection signs > and >> can be prefixed with 1 for the standard output (same as no prefix) or 2 for the standard error.

title: < filename
b
Redirect standard input to read from the named file.
> filename
b
Redirect standard output to write to the named file, overwriting its previous contents.
>> filename
b
Redirect standard output to write to the named file, appending to the end of its previous contents.
>&h
b
Redirect to handle h, where handle is any of 0—standard input, 1—standard output, 2—standard error, and more.
<&h
b
Redirect from handle h.

inline_content.Text: Redirect standard input to read from the named file.
Redirect standard output to write to the named file, overwriting its previous contents.
Redirect standard output to write to the named file, appending to the end of its previous contents.
Redirect to handle h, where handle is any of 0—standard input, 1—standard output, 2—standard error, and more.

title: Redirects the output of the dir command to listing.log file.

inline_content.Text: Redirects the output of the dir command to listing.log file.

title: As above; the space before the file name makes no difference. However, if you type this into the command window, auto-completion with tab after typing "> l" actually works, while it does not work with ">listing.log".

inline_content.Text: As above; the space before the file name makes no difference. However, if you type this into the command window, auto-completion with tab after typing "> l" actually works, while it does not work with ">listing.log".

title: Redirects errors of the dir command to nowhere.

inline_content.Text: Redirects errors of the dir command to nowhere.

title: Redirects the output of the dir command to listing.log file, appending to the file. Thereby, the content of the file before the redirected command was executed does not get lost.

inline_content.Text: Redirects the output of the dir command to listing.log file, appending to the file. Thereby, the content of the file before the redirected command was executed does not get lost.

title: Redirects the output of the dir command to listing.log file, along with the error messages.

inline_content.Text: Redirects the output of the dir command to listing.log file, along with the error messages.

title: Redirects the output of the dir command to listing.log file, and the error messages to listing-errors.log file.

inline_content.Text: Redirects the output of the dir command to listing.log file, and the error messages to listing-errors.log file.

title: The redirection can precede the command.

inline_content.Text: The redirection can precede the command.

title: Output of both echos gets redirected.

inline_content.Text: Output of both echos gets redirected.

title: Redirects console input (con) to the file. Thus, allows multi-line user input terminated by user pressing Control + Z. See also
#User input
a
https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Windows_Batch_Scripting#User_input

inline_content.Text: Redirects console input (con) to the file. Thus, allows multi-line user input terminated by user pressing Control + Z. See also

title: Redirects the entire output of the loop to the file.

inline_content.Text: Redirects the entire output of the loop to the file.

title: Starts redirection anew each time the body of the loop is entered, losing the output of all but the latest loop iteration.

inline_content.Text: Starts redirection anew each time the body of the loop is entered, losing the output of all but the latest loop iteration.

a
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/previous-versions/windows/it-pro/windows-xp/bb490982%28v%3dtechnet.10%29
